specificLearningOutcomes: identify suitable materials for making compost manure
prepare compost manure for farming
appreciate importance of compost manure in farming
suggestedLearningExperiences: discuss suitable materials for compost manure based on their local environment
collect and compost suitable materials and make compost manure using heap method
practise the learnt skills in making compost manure using slashed vegetation, kitchen wastes and any other available organic wastes and using it in their gardening activities
make use of the prepared compost in a crop garden to appreciate its importance
keyInquiryQuestions: How can composting conserve the environment?
coreCompetencies: Communication and collaboration: speaking and listening skills as the learners discuss the process of preparing compost manure
values: Unity: working together striving to achieve common goal in the preparation of compost manure
pcis: Care for the environment as learner utilize waste organic materials in the preparation of compost manure
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate the environmental resource conservation skills to the waste disposal methods learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: describe drip irrigation as a way of conserving water
carry out drip irrigation to conserve water
appreciate use of drip irrigation to conserve water in farming
suggestedLearningExperiences: watch video clips or use print media or observe drip irrigation in neighbouring households to guide them discuss drip irrigation concept
innovate drip irrigation equipment using water pipes and available containers and use the drip irrigation in gardening activities
make use of the innovative drip irrigation equipment in watering crops to appreciate its role in water conservation
keyInquiryQuestions: How do we use drip irrigation to conserve water?
coreCompetencies: Creativity and imagination: creativity skills in experimenting new ideas while innovating drip irrigation equipment
values: Responsibility: undertaking tasks allocated in the innovative drip irrigation project
pcis: Safety of self and others as the learners handle and work with tools and equipment in innovating drip irrigation
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate construction skills in the construction of drip irrigation to skill in use of tools in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify types of fuels used at home
conserve fuels during cooking
appreciate the importance of conserving fuel to minimise wastage of resources
suggestedLearningExperiences: discuss to enumerate the types of fuels such as charcoal, firewood, gas and kerosene used at home
practise ways of conserving fuels such as putting off fire when done and using fuel efficient equipment when cooking
discuss and make presentations on importance of conserving fuels to minimise wastage
keyInquiryQuestions: How does reducing fuel wastage conserve our resources?
coreCompetencies: Critical thinking and problem solving: evaluation and decision making skills as learners explore ways of reducing wastage in use of fuels
values: Responsibility: solving problems proactively as learners use fuels conservatively
pcis: Safety of self and others as learners use fuels and related fires
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate the skills in conservation of fuels to types and sources of energy learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify small wild animals that destroy crops
construct and use a scarecrow to scare off small wild animals from crops
appreciate the importance of living better with small wild animals
suggestedLearningExperiences: brainstorm and share experiences on small wild animals such as birds, hares, squirrels and monkeys that destroy crops
discuss, construct a scarecrow using locally available materials and place the scarecrows in the immediate environment to scare off small wild animals
discuss and make presentations on importance of coexisting with small world animals in the environment
keyInquiryQuestions: How can we scare off small wild animals from crop enterprises?
coreCompetencies: Creativity and imagination: observation and experimentation skills as learners construct scarecrow to scare off wild animals
values: Responsibility: engaging in assigned roles and duties as learners construct the scarecrow to scare off wild animals
pcis: Conservation of biodiversity as learners construct scarecrow to scare off wild animals without killing them
linkToOtherSubjects: Social Studies: Learners relate conservation of wild animals as part of natural resources learnt in Social Studies

specificLearningOutcomes: identify crops established through direct sowing of tiny seeds
sow tiny seeds in a finely prepared seedbed
adopt direct sowing in establishment of food crops
suggestedLearningExperiences: discuss to enumerate food crops such as carrots and millet that are established through direct sowing of tiny seeds (crops that do not require transplanting)
sow the tiny seeds in a finely prepared ground or container seedbed
take care of the tiny seeded crops in a seedbed to adopt the use of direct sowing in food production
keyInquiryQuestions: How does direct sowing of tiny seeds enhance food production process?
coreCompetencies: Learning to learn: own reflection as learners establish tiny seeds in a prepared seedbed
values: Respect: accommodation of diverse opinions while the learners undertake seed bed preparation tasks
pcis: Food and nutritional security as learners grow crops on prepared seedbeds to contribute to food availability at household level
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate the use of tools and equipment in preparation of seedbed and sowing tiny seeds to concepts of tools in making work easier learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify fruits that can grow the locality
grow a fruit crop suited in the locality
appreciate the importance of consuming fruits for nutrition
suggestedLearningExperiences: brainstorm and share information on different types of fruits that can grow in their locality

establish and take care of a fruit crop that can suitably grow in the locality such as woody fruit tree (for example, tree tomato and guava) and climbing fruit crops (such as passion fruit, kiwi, grapes, blackberries, raspberries)
harvest ripe fruits for consumption to appreciate their importance in the body
coreCompetencies: Self-efficacy: self- confidence as learners realise the benefit of growing own fruit crops for consumption
values: Responsibility: as learners take care of growing fruit crops
pcis: Health promotion awareness as learners appreciate the importance of consuming fruits
linkToOtherSubjects: Social Studies: Learners relate growing of fruit crop as an economic activity learnt in Social Studies

specificLearningOutcomes: identify types of domestic animals in the community
relate various domestic animals to their uses
appreciate the importance of domestic animals for food production
suggestedLearningExperiences: share experiences on the types of domestic animals (cattle, sheep, goats, poultry) found in their community and their uses
match the domestic animals to their uses (cattle, sheep, goat and poultry)
make class presentations using photos or other visuals on importance of domestic animals in food production
keyInquiryQuestions: How do domestic animals contribute to food production?
coreCompetencies: Self-efficacy: self-confidence as learners make presentations on uses of domestic animals
values: Respect: open mindedness as learners listen and accommodate others opinions during presentations on importance of domestic animals
pcis: Animal welfare as the learners appreciate importance of domestic animals to humans
linkToOtherSubjects: Social Studies: Learners relate animals reared in their community to knowledge learnt in Social Studies on social economic activities

specificLearningOutcomes: explain importance of eating a balanced meal
select food from different food groups to make a balanced meal
appreciate the importance of eating a balanced meal
suggestedLearningExperiences: discuss or use digital devices to search for importance of eating a balanced meal (variety and proportion)
select foods from locally available foods to comprise a balanced meal (energy giving, body building and protective foods)
keep a journal for one week on meals they take to appreciate the importance of a balanced meal
keyInquiryQuestions: How does a balanced meal impact on health?
coreCompetencies: Communication and collaboration: team work as learners contribute in the discussion on importance of a balanced meal
values: Unity: collaboration with others as learners select foods to comprise balanced meal
pcis: Health awareness promotion as learners discuss the importance of eating a balanced meal
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate the importance of eating balanced meal to knowledge learnt in Science and Technology on healthy eating habits

specificLearningOutcomes: describe methods of cooking food
cook food using different methods
embrace boiling and shallow frying in food production
suggestedLearningExperiences: watch video clip or demonstration on boiling and shallow frying methods of cooking
cook food using boiling and shallow frying methods
serve the boiled and shallow fried food to embrace the various methods of food production
keyInquiryQuestions: How can we cook food using boiling and shallow frying methods?
coreCompetencies: Learning to learn: organizing own learning as learners apply laid down procedure in boiling and shallow frying food
values: Responsibility: observes care and safety when boiling and shallow frying food
pcis: Safety of self and others to avoid accidents as they boil and fry food
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate handling of accidents to first aid skills learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify healthy practices that promote personal hygiene
apply healthy practices that promote personal hygiene
embrace healthy practices to promote personal hygiene in daily life
suggestedLearningExperiences: brainstorm and enumerate practices that promote personal hygiene such as hand washing, use of personal protective equipment and use of clean water
demonstrate appropriate practices that promote personal hygiene such as hand washing, use of personal protective equipment and use of clean water
keep a day-to-day activity log of various hygiene practices for a specified period of time to embrace personal health promotion
keyInquiryQuestions: How does personal hygiene promote good health?
coreCompetencies: Self-efficacy: skills in enhancement of self-outlook for self and others through personal hygiene practices
values: Responsibility: taking charge of own body as they practise personal hygiene and use personal protective equipment
pcis: Prevention of communicable diseases as learners practise personal hygiene
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate personal hygiene practices to prevention of communicable diseases learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: describe the various methods used for cleaning home environment
use appropriate methods to clean home environment
appreciate a clean environment in promoting domestic hygiene
suggestedLearningExperiences: discuss the methods of cleaning home environment such as mopping, dusting, sweeping and disposal of refuse
apply the methods such as mopping, dusting, sweeping and disposal of refuse to maintain hygiene in the environment
maintain clean living environment using applicable methods in their classroom contexts while using improvised and locally available resources
keyInquiryQuestions: How can we maintain hygiene in the home environment?
coreCompetencies: Creativity and imagination: thoughtful choices as learners use improvised and locally available cleaning resources
values: Responsibility: accountability as learners engage in activities of cleaning home environment
pcis: Environmental awareness as learners maintain clean healthy environment
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate clean environment to control of communicable diseases learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify personal protective equipment in day to day life
clean personal protective equipment for hygiene purposes
appreciate clean personal protective equipment in promoting hygiene
suggestedLearningExperiences: search for information or observe a demonstration to identify common personal protective equipment such as gloves, dust masks, gumboots, headgear, overall and canvas shoes
apply appropriate methods to clean personal protective equipment such as gumboots or canvas shoes
make display of cleaned personal protective equipment to appreciate and promote hygiene
keyInquiryQuestions: How does cleaning of personal protective equipment promote hygiene?
coreCompetencies: Digital literacy: use of digital technology as learners search for information on personal protective equipment
values: Responsibility: safety and care of self as learners clean personal protective equipment
pcis: Personal safety as learners exercise caution while undertaking cleaning activity
linkToOtherSubjects: Science and Technology: Learners relate use of personal protective equipment to personal safety skills learnt in Science and Technology

specificLearningOutcomes: identify the types of tacking stitches in sewing
make an item using tacking stitches
appreciate the importance of tacking stitches
suggestedLearningExperiences: observe samples of tacking stitches (even tacking; long and short tacking) used in sewing
make sample item such as a handkerchief or clothing for a scarecrow using tacking (even tacking or long and short taking) stitches
make presentations using a display of sample items to appreciate the importance of tacking stitches
keyInquiryQuestions: How can we use tacking stitches in making items?
coreCompetencies: Creativity and imagination: experimentation skills as learners observe, innovate and try out on tacking stitches
values: Unity: display of team spirit as learners share resources in the making of tacking stitches
pcis: Safety of self and others as learners use needles and other sharp tools in sewing task
linkToOtherSubjects: Mathematics: Leaners relate skills in measuring materials and precision in tacking stitches to measurements in Mathematics
